title: Goodbye pixel fonts & hinting.
content:
Check out the resolution of this baby!  
 [  
http://www.digitaltvdesignline.com/encyclopedia/defineterm.jhtml?term=microdisplay](http://web.archive.org/web/20080118191412/http:/www.digitaltvdesignline.com/encyclopedia/defineterm.jhtml?term=microdisplay)

Imagine a future world where all displays have this much detail. Would the digital and print seam of typography be wiped out? Will we have interactive ’print’? Or will something else weird happen? Like fonts embedded with enhancer animations that play whenever the font is loaded/seen. Or embedded complimentary voice overs for readers. We won’t be designing typefaces anymore, people. Today is the dawn of the typebody.

comments.content: Something tells me that that photo is not very recent. The display shows IE/Mac running on OS 8 or 9, judging by the window appearance.
Don’t overlook the © 1999 right above it. That aside, I was merely fantasizing about how the type would change if resolution were increased tenfold.

_Don’t overlook the © 1999 right above it._

That reminds me of this Sherlock Holmes cartoon I just saw on the web. Holmes deduces where a murder has just occurred by carefully following a bullet’s trajectory to a house across the street. Watson tells him he already had figured that out because of all the police standing outside the house.

<cite>...fonts embedded with enhancer animations...</cite>

Go-go, coming soon from House Industries and Coop!.

LOL!!! “...he already had figured that out because of all the police standing outside the house.”

Kinda like giving a breathalizer test to a guy who smells like a brewery :-)

ChrisL

I doubt the human eye would see a difference between tenfold and thousandfold screen density increases.

Assuming most screens are around 100ppi at the moment, a 4 fold increase to 1600ppi would be pretty damn close to high end printing on paper.

What base are you using? Because in base 10, 100 times 4 is 400... You seem to mean binary orders of magnitude, but I don’t think that’s what koleslaw meant.

BTW, even though the eye seems to bottom out at 1000dpi when it comes to consciously detecting specific micro features, when it comes to things like equal counters in an “m” (think: hinting) or the texture/color of a block of small text the eye can quite easily detect the difference between 1200 and 2400dpi printing, so...

hhp
yea, it depends on how we mathematically define ’fold’ ;o)
